text.0: for thee may indra boldly speed the car that works on either side.
text.1: favour us muchinvoked in this most glorious fight against the raiders of our wealth.
text.2: loose in the wind the womans robe was streaming what time she won a carload worth a thousand.
text.3: the charioteer in fight was mudgalani she indras dart heaped up the prize of battle.
text.4: o indra cast thy bolt among assailants who would slaughter us.
text.5: the weapon both of dāsa and of Ārya foe keep far away o maghavan.
text.6: the bull in joy had drunk a lake of water his shattering horn encountered an opponent.
text.7: swiftly in vigorous strength eager for glory he stretched his forefeet fain to win and triumph.
text.8: they came anear the bull they made him thunder made him pour rain down ere the fight was ended.
text.9: and mudgala thereby won in the contest wellpastured kine in hundreds and in thousands.
text.10: in hope of victory that bull was harnessed kesi the driver urged him on with shouting.
text.11: as he ran swiftly with the car behind him his lifted heels pressed close on mudgalani.
text.12: deftly for him he stretched the carpole forward guided the bull thereto and firmly yoked him.
text.13: indra vouchsafed the lord of cows his favour with mighty steps the buffalo ran onward.
text.14: touched by the goad the shaggy beast went nobly bound to the pole by the yokes thong of leather.
text.15: performing deeds of might for many people he looking on the cows gained strength and vigour.
text.16: here look upon this mace this bulls companion now lying midway on the field of battle.
text.17: therewith hath mudgala in ordered contest won for cattle for himself a hundred thousand.
text.18: far is the evil who hath here beheld it hither they bring the bull whom they are yoking.
text.19: to this they give not either food or water reaching beyond the pole it gives directions.
text.20: like one forsaken she hath found a husband and teemed as if her breast were full and flowing.
text.21: with swiftlyracing chariot may we conquer and rich and blessed be our gains in battle.
text.22: thou indra art the mark whereon the eyes of all life rest when thou.
text.23: a bull who drivest with thy bull wilt win the race together with thy weakling friend.
